summary.topic: my heart rate is unusually high today, let's see how this goes.
summary.summary: 66 might be getting sick. nobody knows what's going on. let's see.

summary.topic: let's talk about selling your work authentically with a story to contextualize it.
summary.summary: today, let's talk about selling your work authentically. to illustrate this, i'll share a story about my dad. he visited san francisco recently, rocking the bill space hoodie, and seeing him helped me figure out how to be authentic in selling my work.

summary.topic: the story starts with my dad, who was born in Pakistan and moved to America in the early 90s.
summary.summary: born in pakistan, he came to america in the early 90s. my mom sent me this picture of him today; i'd never seen it before. he's the classic immigrant story.

summary.topic: my dad did various jobs, drove taxis, flipped pizzas, and eventually got a job selling cars at Nissan.
summary.summary: drove taxis, flipped pizzas at s pizza, and mostly drove taxis in new york city and miami. did a bunch of restaurant work too. in the late 90s, he got a job selling cars at nissan in miami. that's him on the right.

summary.topic: over 25 years, he became one of the top-ranked car salesmen in the country.
summary.summary: over 25 years later, my dad works at one of the top-performing car dealerships in the country. every year, he's either ranked number one or top in his region by performance percentage. he's a sales machine and hasn't left the car business since he started; he even worked at toyota when i was in middle and high school.

summary.topic: during middle school, I often did homework in his office and observed his customer interactions.
summary.summary: i loved going to his office after school to do homework. his office had coffee and popcorn, and i'd sit there listening to him talk to customers, learning a lot in the process.

summary.topic: my dad never tried to aggressively sell; he focused on understanding the customer.
summary.summary: over the years, watching my dad work at the dealership, i noticed he never tried to push or sell anything aggressively. instead, he focused on understanding the customer and then making an offer that suited both them and him after some time. growing up around this, i couldn't help but compare his approach to other salespeople who often used more forceful tactics.

summary.topic: comparing him to other salespeople, I noticed they often felt like delivering an ad rather than connecting personally.
summary.summary: i used to watch my dad and others, and they always had this vibe like used car salespeople, always trying to lock you into a deal. they'd say stuff like, "we have a package with leather seats for just $1,000 more," or "the Honda Accord has a feature for $2,000 more, but since you're here, it's 25% off." they'd hype up the features, calling it the best in its class just to make a sale.

summary.topic: many of you are resembling these stereotypical sales tactics, and it's reflected in your project's lack of movement.
summary.summary: generally, these sales pitches get awkward replies like "oh interesting, i'll let you know," or "not right now." it felt like the salespeople were delivering an ad in person. turns out many of you are being that awkward salesperson. based on last friday's exam day, 15 projects were flat or down, 11 were slightly up without much effort, and only two showed a significant push, indicating that effective selling is not happening.

summary.topic: 50% of the projects made zero movement, which is alarming and suggests a selling problem.
summary.summary: 50% of you made no progress last week, which is surprising because I see the effort you're all putting in. It seems like the issue might be time or personal management rather than laziness. According to the data, the main problem appears to be your ability to sell rather than a lack of effort or work.

summary.topic: a common excuse is the unfinished or unpresentable state of the current work.
summary.summary: the reality is that everything is always going to be crappy and unfinished. people think facebook is still crappy and unfinished, and that's just how it will always feel. despite this, everyone has something to show and should recognize the value in what they have, no matter how early or imperfect it seems.

summary.topic: everyone thinks their work is crappy and unfinished, but that's always going to be the case.
summary.summary: improve your skills and craft, whether you're an engineer, designer, or something else. when it comes to selling, don't pretend your product is the best. instead, find the people who appreciate what you truly have, even if it's an old, rusty 1996 civic.

summary.topic: you need to focus on improving your skills and selling what you have.
summary.summary: you're trying to sell a rusty old car like it's a mercedes, which is exhausting. stop pretending and just focus on selling what you have. you're good at it.

summary.topic: you don't need to sell it like a top-tier product; find the right target audience who will value it.
summary.summary: you're all good at selling because you know your product, you can demo it, and you can have normal conversations without being weird. you're good at taking feedback without getting too personal. today, i'll cover three strategies to help you improve your selling game over the next few days and weeks.

summary.topic: stop marketing and start selling – there's a clear difference between the two.
summary.summary: stop marketing, start selling. marketing is building an audience for your work and encouraging them to engage, like apple or nike campaigns. selling is getting that audience to take the desired action, such as a purchase, follow, or use of your product.

summary.topic: marketing is building an audience; selling is getting them to take an action you want.
summary.summary: selling is about getting someone to take the action you want, unlike marketing. don't just think of it as exchanging goods for money. most of you need to understand this difference.

summary.topic: many projects are focused on marketing rather than directly converting actions.
summary.summary: most of you start with an email, Reddit post, TikTok, reel, or Twitter post, expecting people to then visit your landing page or link tree. from there, you expect them to take multiple actions like listening to your song or subscribing. realize this involves four steps, which is pretty hard to achieve. industry average numbers back up how challenging this process is.

summary.topic: the current approach involves multiple steps, reducing potential conversions drastically.
summary.summary: 100% of people will watch your Instagram reel, 10% will visit your profile or click your link, 1% may click to create an account or preorder, and 0.5% will actually take action. To put it in real numbers, if 100 people see your post, 10 will click the link, 1 will click the CTA, and 0.5 will follow through.

summary.topic: even with 1000 views, the conversion rate might leave you with only 5 active users.
summary.summary: if you send a 100 people to your stuff and nothing happens, it's because the math is against you. to succeed, you need to send way more people; think a thousand. from those, a small fraction will engage and even fewer will complete your desired action, like buying a shirt or listening to your song.

summary.topic: try going directly to the target users instead of through multiple steps.
summary.summary: reality check: not everyone will stick around for your ideas, and only a small percent will stay till the end. it's fine, just keep moving forward. instead of aiming to get many people, focus on directly reaching the few you really need. an example: at bill space, starting out without much marketing, we still managed by going directly to the right people.

summary.topic: an example from buildspace: early targeting of college CS Discord groups worked better than broader marketing.
summary.summary: we optimized for selling by creating college-themed landing pages for each college and targeting cs discord groups. this targeted approach worked because our initial users came from these groups and it resulted in building strong relationships with over 100 moderators, bringing in about 3,500 users. instead of broad strategies like making tiktoks, focusing on direct channels to reach our audience of college cs students proved highly effective.

summary.topic: consider direct and personalized approaches, like Daniel calling co-working spaces instead of making content.
summary.summary: co-working spaces, schools, hackers' houses, companies—each could benefit from our product to increase focus. Try selling directly to these groups instead of relying on marketing. Another idea involves engaging with local chess clubs, tournaments, or even chess streamers to promote Chessy. Focus on direct face-to-face interactions for more effective results compared to broad marketing strategies.

summary.topic: offer valuable face-to-face interactions, even if it seems time-consuming.
summary.summary: go to where your people are and have a direct conversation or show them the product. it's worth compromising cash flow at first to give people a taste of what you offer. that familiarity can be valuable.

summary.topic: in early stages, optimizing for direct engagement is crucial.
summary.summary: if you're low on cash, find ways to make money through your work, like hosting a concert for a small audience or getting your music played at a club. prioritize high-value activities that don't require much effort, like joining relevant online communities. keep in mind that these strategies might eventually stop working, so be ready to adapt. while you're still small, use your ability to connect with people individually to build interest and support.

summary.topic: give personalized attention to potential users; that direct connection can make a difference.
summary.summary: your real power is that you're an individual who cares about your work, not just another NPC trying to sell something on tiktok. it's crucial to never underestimate this.

summary.topic: personal approach helps, like my interaction with my first customer at Zip Homeschool.
summary.summary: i started zip homeschool with nothing but my time and a fake partner named griffin. my first customer, lucy moore, needed targeted exercises for her daughter, so i personalized lessons each week after learning what she struggled with. over time, i got better and eventually hired help, but the key was always personal attention—something big companies can't match.

summary.topic: differentiate between meaningful conversations and superficial networking.
summary.summary: networking is making fake friends and connections for selfish reasons to advance yourself. conversation means just getting to know each other, which is different. anisha and amar are working on an ai shopping assistant but face challenges with user engagement. a suggested solution is to offer live, one-on-one calls to help users buy products, potentially increasing success.

summary.topic: real examples: helping users individually through calls or personalized sessions can be more effective.
summary.summary: think one-on-one interactions can be built into anything you do. take an example of a personal diabetes assistant; instead of pitching it as $20 a month, book one-on-one calls and show users the product directly. personal interaction can convert more people, similar to how a meaningful encounter with your favorite artist can turn you into a lifelong supporter. aim to have more direct conversations with potential users to better understand their needs and build a loyal user base.

summary.topic: choose easier targets to sell to initially; don't pick the hardest audience.
summary.summary: we built a cloud ide for college students to save them from spending the first week setting up coding environments. we tried selling it to schools, but they take forever to sign contracts, so we shifted to selling directly to students, which also failed because students have no money. in hindsight, we should've targeted easier markets, like tutors for younger kids.

summary.topic: selling to students or educational institutions is tough; consider easier, adjacent markets instead.
summary.summary: we were so locked into student life that we ignored advice about the difficulties we'd face starting a company. we were stubborn and chose the hardest people to sell to, kind of like many of you might. you can make it easier by adjusting your target audience without massive shifts; for example, selling clothing to companies in bulk can be more effective than selling to individual consumers.

summary.topic: continuously explore potential user bases that may require less effort to convert.
summary.summary: experiment with who you're trying to reach; it's okay if you're unsure, you can ask us. bonnie's idea of targeting gift shops is interesting, though it's important to stay flexible in case they don't respond. explore other places where your product could be sold without much effort.

summary.topic: it's essential to remain flexible and experiment with different customer segments.
summary.summary: if selling to medical students seems too hard, maybe it's time to switch strategies. try targeting a different, slightly adjacent group instead. it might help you get your foot in the door with less struggle.
